comment.author: 18753752@N00
comment._content: I think this is the same ship: www.norwayheritage.com/p_ship.asp?sh=finla

comment.author: 11572312@N00
comment._content: In light of the sign on deck that seems to say "American", here is a link to an article about the American Line (related to the Red Star Line that is tagged above). en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Line Here is article about the USS Finland: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USS_Finland This article mentions that: "In 1912, Finland was chartered by the American Olympic Committee to take the U.S. team to the 1912 Summer Olympics in Stockholm, Sweden." (so that MAY be the news connection for this photo).

comment.author: 8348059@N02
comment._content: The sign with "American" appears to be on the pier, not on the ship. It may be for American Line, which was a unit of International Mercantile Marine along with Red Star Line. Agree that the news photo was probably due to the chartering of Finland to transport the 1912 US Olympic Team.

comment.author: 19132792@N00
comment._content: She sailed primarily to ports in the United Kingdom, Belgium, and Italy. She also briefly sailed on New York to San Francisco, California, service. Another netpage: www.history.navy.mil/photos/sh-civil/civsh-f/finland.htm Originally S.S.Finland, she was designated USS Finland, after being commissioned by the US Navy in 1917.

comment.author: 29079609@N02
comment._content: the sign is not on deck, you can see it is behind the davits on the far side of the boat, it is on the American Line dock building

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: Story in the New York Times, February 27, 1912, discusses plans for the trip: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9905E0D6173CE6...
